title: Obstructive Sleep Apnea — Neurological Evaluation
scope: ** Neurological evaluation and management of obstructive sleep apnea in adults. Focuses on neurology-specific aspects: stroke risk assessment, cognitive impact, epilepsy interaction, headache relationship, and neuropathy/autonomic effects. Excludes primary pulmonary/ENT management, central sleep apnea (separate entity), and pediatric OSA. Complements pulmonology/sleep medicine primary management.

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Screen for polycythemia secondary to chronic intermittent hypoxia; anemia contributing to fatigue
Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal; elevated Hgb/Hct suggests chronic hypoxemia

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Renal/hepatic function; electrolytes; pre-treatment baseline; assess metabolic syndrome components
Hypothyroidism causes weight gain, upper airway edema, and fatigue that exacerbates OSA
Metabolic syndrome screening; OSA independently increases insulin resistance and type 2 diabetes risk
Dyslipidemia screening for cerebrovascular risk stratification; OSA promotes atherogenic lipid profile
Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).target: LDL <100 mg/dL (or <70 if high vascular risk)

Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).rationale: Systemic inflammation marker; OSA-related chronic inflammation contributes to atherosclerosis and neurological injury
Essential/Core Labs (All Patients).target: Normal; elevated suggests high inflammatory burden

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Cardiac strain assessment; OSA-related pulmonary hypertension and right heart dysfunction; screen for heart failure contributing to central apneas
Stroke risk assessment; baseline before anticoagulation if atrial fibrillation detected
Elevated homocysteine is independent cerebrovascular risk factor; compounds OSA-related stroke risk
Assess HPA axis dysfunction from chronic sleep fragmentation; cortisol dysregulation contributes to metabolic syndrome

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome assessment when awake PaCO2 elevation suspected; chronic hypercapnia
Rare/Specialized.target: pH 7.35-7.45; PaCO2 35-45 mmHg; elevated PaCO2 suggests OHS

Rare/Specialized.item: Hypercoagulability panel (Factor V Leiden, prothrombin mutation, antiphospholipid antibodies, protein C/S, antithrombin III)
Rare/Specialized.rationale: Young stroke patient with OSA; evaluate for additional thrombophilic risk factors compounding OSA-related stroke risk
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal; positive results require hematology referral

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Screen for B12 deficiency contributing to cognitive impairment and neuropathy in OSA patients

Essential/First-line.timing: Gold standard diagnostic study; in-lab attended study with EEG, EMG, ECG, airflow, respiratory effort, oximetry
Essential/First-line.target: AHI calculation; severity classification; oxygen desaturation nadir and duration; assessment of sleep architecture disruption

Essential/First-line.timing: Alternative to PSG for uncomplicated patients without significant comorbidity; measures airflow, respiratory effort, oximetry
Essential/First-line.target: AHI/REI ≥5 with symptoms or ≥15 without symptoms; may underestimate severity
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Suspected central apnea, hypoventilation, significant cardiopulmonary disease, neuromuscular disease; not valid if negative in high-pretest-probability patient

Essential/First-line.timing: Administer at initial evaluation and each follow-up to track treatment response
Essential/First-line.target: ESS ≤10 (normal); ≥11 indicates pathological sleepiness requiring intervention

Essential/First-line.timing: Screening tool for undiagnosed OSA; administer to all patients with stroke, cognitive decline, refractory seizures, or morning headache
Essential/First-line.target: Score ≥3 warrants formal sleep study; score ≥5 high probability of moderate-severe OSA

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If stroke symptoms, cognitive decline, or white matter disease suspected; assess for silent cerebral infarcts and leukoaraiosis
Extended.target: White matter hyperintensities (leukoaraiosis); silent infarcts; hippocampal atrophy; no acute stroke

Extended.timing: Cerebrovascular risk assessment; OSA promotes carotid intima-media thickening and plaque formation through intermittent hypoxia
Extended.target: Normal intima-media thickness (<1.0 mm); no significant stenosis

Extended.timing: If seizure concern; OSA lowers seizure threshold; evaluate for nocturnal seizures mimicking or coexisting with OSA
Extended.target: Normal background; no epileptiform discharges; distinguish from OSA-related arousals

Extended.timing: Formal assessment of OSA-related cognitive impairment; evaluate attention, executive function, memory, processing speed
Extended.target: Baseline performance; identify deficits in attention, executive function, visuospatial processing, and memory

Rare/Specialized.timing: Cerebrovascular assessment if stroke or TIA with OSA; evaluate for intracranial stenosis and vertebrobasilar disease
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal arterial anatomy; no significant stenosis or aneurysm
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Per MRI contraindications; renal function if gadolinium

Rare/Specialized.timing: If pulmonary hypertension, right heart failure, or atrial fibrillation suspected; OSA is leading cause of secondary pulmonary hypertension
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal RV size/function; RVSP <35 mmHg; no atrial enlargement; assess for patent foramen ovale (paradoxical embolism risk)

Rare/Specialized.item: Autonomic function testing (tilt table, QSART, cardiovagal testing)
Rare/Specialized.timing: If autonomic neuropathy suspected; OSA causes sympathetic hyperactivation and parasympathetic withdrawal
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal autonomic reflexes; document sympathovagal imbalance severity

CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.indication: First-line OSA treatment with demonstrated neuroprotective benefit; reduces stroke risk 40-60% in compliant users; improves cognitive function; reduces seizure frequency in comorbid epilepsy

doseOptions.orderSentence: CPAP therapy (continuous positive airway pressure) N/A nasal/oronasal

dosing.instructions: Titrated to eliminate obstructive events per PSG or auto-CPAP algorithm; target AHI <5 on therapy; minimum 4 hours/night for clinical benefit; optimal ≥6 hours/night
dosing.orderSentence: CPAP therapy (continuous positive airway pressure) N/A nasal/oronasal

CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.contraindications: Inability to clear secretions; CSF leak; basilar skull fracture; severe bullous lung disease
CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.monitoring: CPAP compliance data download every 1-3 months; residual AHI on device; mask leak; ESS improvement; blood pressure response

CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.indication: Adjunct for position-dependent OSA where AHI is ≥2x worse supine; reduces neurological impact of positional desaturation

dosing.instructions: Positional devices (tennis ball technique, commercial positional belts, or wedge pillows) to maintain lateral sleep position

CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.contraindications: Inability to tolerate lateral position; musculoskeletal limitations
CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.monitoring: Symptom response; repeat PSG or HSAT to confirm efficacy

CPAP Optimization for Neurological Benef.indication: Consolidate nocturnal sleep; reduce OSA severity; improve CPAP tolerance

dosing.instructions: Regular sleep-wake schedule; 7-9 hours nightly; cool dark room; elevate head of bed 30 degrees; avoid supine position; limit screen time before bed

Neurological Comorbidity Management.indication: Residual EDS despite compliant CPAP therapy (≥4 hours/night for ≥3 months); FDA-approved for residual sleepiness in OSA

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg each morning; increase to 200 mg daily after 1-2 weeks if needed; max 200 mg/day for OSA-related EDS; take upon awakening

Neurological Comorbidity Management.contraindications: Hypersensitivity; severe hepatic impairment; may reduce efficacy of hormonal contraceptives; verify CPAP compliance before prescribing
Neurological Comorbidity Management.monitoring: Blood pressure; rash (rare Stevens-Johnson); sleep quality; CPAP compliance verification; contraceptive efficacy

Neurological Comorbidity Management.indication: Central apnea component; altitude-related OSA exacerbation; reduces AHI by increasing ventilatory drive through metabolic acidosis

dosing.instructions: Start 250 mg BID; may increase to 500 mg BID; reduces AHI by 40-50% in mixed/central apnea component; also useful for idiopathic intracranial hypertension comorbidity

Neurological Comorbidity Management.contraindications: Sulfonamide allergy; severe hepatic or renal insufficiency; hyponatremia; hypokalemia; metabolic acidosis
Neurological Comorbidity Management.monitoring: Electrolytes (K+, bicarb) at 1 week and monthly; renal function; paresthesias (common, benign); nephrolithiasis risk

Neurological Comorbidity Management.indication: Weight reduction and migraine prophylaxis in obese OSA patients with comorbid migraine; dual benefit of weight loss (reduces AHI) and headache prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 25 mg at bedtime; titrate by 25 mg/week to target 50-100 mg BID; weight loss benefit typically requires ≥100 mg/day; max 200 mg/day

Neurological Comorbidity Management.contraindications: Metabolic acidosis; nephrolithiasis history; pregnancy (teratogenic); acute narrow-angle glaucoma
Neurological Comorbidity Management.monitoring: Serum bicarbonate; renal function; cognitive effects (word-finding difficulty); weight; kidney stones; intraocular pressure if eye symptoms

Stroke Prevention in OSA.indication: Cardiovascular risk reduction in moderate-severe OSA with vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, smoking); primary prevention when 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10%

dosing.instructions: 81 mg once daily; take with food; continue indefinitely unless contraindicated

Stroke Prevention in OSA.contraindications: Active GI bleeding; aspirin allergy; severe thrombocytopenia; concurrent anticoagulation (relative); last trimester pregnancy
Stroke Prevention in OSA.monitoring: GI symptoms; bleeding signs; platelet count if concern; concurrent NSAID use

Stroke Prevention in OSA.indication: Dyslipidemia management with OSA-related vascular risk; statins provide pleiotropic anti-inflammatory benefit relevant to OSA-induced endothelial dysfunction

dosing.instructions: Start 20 mg daily; increase to 40 mg daily if LDL goal not met at 6 weeks; take in evening; high-intensity statin (40-80 mg) if ASCVD equivalent or prior stroke

Stroke Prevention in OSA.contraindications: Active liver disease; pregnancy; breastfeeding; concurrent cyclosporine
Stroke Prevention in OSA.monitoring: LFTs at baseline and 12 weeks; lipid panel at 6 weeks; CK if myalgia; assess diabetes risk

Stroke Prevention in OSA.indication: Resistant hypertension commonly driven by untreated OSA; OSA is leading identifiable cause of resistant hypertension; CPAP reduces BP 2-10 mmHg

dosing.instructions: Optimize existing antihypertensive regimen; target BP <130/80 mmHg; CPAP adherence is critical adjunct; consider aldosterone antagonist (spironolactone) for resistant hypertension with OSA

Stroke Prevention in OSA.monitoring: Blood pressure at each visit; home BP monitoring; electrolytes if on spironolactone; assess CPAP compliance as adjunct to pharmacotherapy

Seizure Management with OSA.indication: Comorbid epilepsy with OSA; untreated OSA increases seizure frequency through sleep fragmentation and intermittent hypoxia; CPAP reduces seizure frequency by up to 50%

doseOptions.orderSentence: CPAP optimization for seizure control N/A nasal/oronasal

dosing.instructions: Optimize CPAP compliance targeting ≥6 hours/night; seizure frequency reduction correlates with CPAP adherence; may allow AED dose reduction once OSA controlled
dosing.orderSentence: CPAP optimization for seizure control N/A nasal/oronasal

Seizure Management with OSA.monitoring: Seizure diary; CPAP compliance; AED levels; EEG if breakthrough seizures

Seizure Management with OSA.indication: Avoid sedating AEDs that worsen OSA through respiratory depression, weight gain, and upper airway muscle relaxation

doseOptions.orderSentence: AED selection guidance in OSA N/A PO

dosing.instructions: AVOID: phenobarbital, benzodiazepines (clonazepam, clorazepate), pregabalin (weight gain, sedation); PREFER: levetiracetam, lamotrigine, lacosamide (weight-neutral, non-sedating); CAUTION: topiramate (weight loss beneficial but cognitive effects); valproate (weight gain worsens OSA)
dosing.orderSentence: AED selection guidance in OSA N/A PO

Seizure Management with OSA.monitoring: Seizure frequency; weight; sedation level; CPAP compliance; sleep quality; AED levels

Referrals & Consults.item: Sleep medicine referral for PSG/HSAT, CPAP titration, and ongoing compliance management; essential for all patients with confirmed or suspected OSA
Neurology follow-up every 3-6 months for cognitive monitoring, stroke risk assessment, seizure management, and headache evaluation in OSA patients with neurological comorbidity

Neuropsychology referral for formal neurocognitive testing if subjective cognitive decline, MoCA <26, or objective cognitive complaints affecting daily function; establishes baseline for CPAP treatment response

Cardiology referral if atrial fibrillation detected, pulmonary hypertension suspected, or resistant hypertension despite optimal medical therapy and CPAP; OSA-related AF requires anticoagulation decision
Endocrinology referral if HbA1c ≥6.5%, uncontrolled metabolic syndrome, or morbid obesity (BMI ≥40) for comprehensive metabolic management that complements OSA treatment
Bariatric surgery evaluation for patients with BMI ≥35 with OSA-related comorbidities or BMI ≥40; weight loss surgery produces sustained AHI reduction and may cure OSA

Patient/Family Instructions.item: OSA is a chronic neurological risk factor that significantly increases stroke risk (2-3 fold) and causes progressive cognitive decline if untreated; CPAP treatment reduces stroke risk by 40-60%
Use CPAP every night for the entire sleep period; minimum 4 hours/night required for cardiovascular benefit; optimal benefit at ≥6 hours/night; even partial use is better than no use
Report new neurological symptoms immediately: sudden weakness, speech difficulty, vision changes, severe headache, numbness, or new seizures (may indicate stroke or neurological complication of OSA)
Do not drive if excessively sleepy; untreated OSA increases motor vehicle accident risk 2-7 fold; resume driving only after EDS is controlled with CPAP (ESS <11)
Avoid alcohol within 3 hours of bedtime; alcohol relaxes upper airway muscles, worsens apneas, and increases nocturnal hypoxemia independently of body position

Avoid sedating medications (benzodiazepines, opioids, sedating antihistamines, muscle relaxants) unless prescribed by a physician aware of OSA diagnosis; these worsen respiratory depression during sleep
Bed partner observations are valuable; report witnessed apneas, gasping, choking, or unusual movements during sleep at each visit

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Weight management: 10% body weight loss produces approximately 26% AHI reduction; even modest weight loss (5-7%) improves oxygen desaturation and reduces cardiovascular risk
Regular aerobic exercise: 150 minutes/week moderate-intensity exercise reduces AHI by 25% independent of weight loss; improves endothelial function and reduces inflammatory markers
Sleep position training: avoid supine sleeping; lateral and prone positions reduce AHI by 50% or more in position-dependent OSA; elevate head of bed 30 degrees
Smoking cessation: smoking increases upper airway inflammation, edema, and OSA severity; smoking is an independent stroke risk factor compounding OSA risk
Limit caffeine to morning hours only to preserve sleep architecture; avoid caffeine after noon; caffeine does not substitute for CPAP therapy
Nasal congestion management with nasal saline rinse and intranasal corticosteroid to improve CPAP tolerance and reduce oral breathing

differential.features: Absent respiratory effort during apneic events; Cheyne-Stokes pattern in heart failure; no snoring during central events; may coexist with OSA (complex sleep apnea)
differential.tests: PSG showing central events >50% of total AHI; absent respiratory effort on chest/abdomen belts

differential.features: Excessive daytime sleepiness with cataplexy; irresistible sleep attacks; sleep paralysis; hypnagogic hallucinations; no snoring or witnessed apneas as primary feature
differential.tests: MSLT showing mean sleep latency ≤8 min with ≥2 SOREMPs; CSF orexin ≤110 pg/mL for type 1

differential.features: Prolonged non-refreshing sleep; severe sleep inertia; excessive total sleep time (>11 hours); no respiratory events on PSG; no apneas
differential.tests: PSG showing normal AHI; MSLT with mean latency ≤8 min but <2 SOREMPs

differential.features: Temporal relationship to sedating medication initiation; sleepiness without respiratory events; no snoring or witnessed apneas
differential.tests: Medication review; PSG showing normal AHI; resolution with dose reduction

differential.features: Stereotyped motor events during sleep; postictal confusion; incontinence; tongue biting; may coexist with OSA
differential.tests: Video-EEG monitoring; PSG with expanded EEG montage; epileptiform discharges

differential.features: Dream enactment behavior; vocalizations; violent limb movements during REM sleep; associated with alpha-synucleinopathies; no respiratory events
differential.tests: PSG showing REM sleep without atonia; video documentation of dream enactment

differential.features: Urge to move legs with uncomfortable sensations; worse at rest and evening; relief with movement; may fragment sleep causing EDS
differential.tests: Clinical diagnosis (IRLSSG criteria); ferritin level; PSG may show periodic limb movements

differential.features: Repetitive stereotyped limb movements during sleep causing arousals; EDS from sleep fragmentation; no respiratory events
differential.tests: PSG showing PLMS index >15/hour without OSA; distinguish from OSA-related arousals

differential.features: Awake hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg) in obese patient (BMI ≥30); daytime hypoxemia; often coexists with severe OSA
differential.tests: ABG showing awake hypercapnia; serum bicarbonate >27 mEq/L; PSG with prolonged hypoxemia

differential.features: Depressed mood; anhedonia; fatigue more than true sleepiness; psychomotor retardation; no respiratory events; may coexist with OSA
differential.tests: PHQ-9; psychiatric evaluation; PSG showing normal AHI; sleepiness does not improve with CPAP

evidence.recommendation: OSA is an independent risk factor for ischemic stroke with 2-3 fold increased risk; dose-response relationship with AHI severity
evidence.source: [Yaggi et al. N Engl J Med 2005](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16306520/)

evidence.recommendation: OSA causes significant neurocognitive impairment including deficits in attention, executive function, visuospatial processing, and memory
CPAP treatment reduces fatal and non-fatal cardiovascular events in severe OSA; untreated severe OSA has significantly higher cardiovascular mortality
Untreated OSA worsens seizure control; CPAP treatment reduces seizure frequency in patients with comorbid epilepsy
OSA-related cognitive deficits are partially reversible with CPAP treatment; attention and executive function show most improvement; memory deficits may persist
OSA prevalence has increased substantially; estimated 10-17% of adult men and 3-9% of adult women affected; prevalence increases with obesity epidemic
evidence.evidenceLevel: Prospective population-based cohort (Wisconsin Sleep Cohort, 20-year follow-up)

evidence.recommendation: 10% body weight loss produces 26% reduction in AHI; weight management is critical adjunct to CPAP therapy
OSA is the most common identifiable cause of resistant hypertension; CPAP reduces blood pressure 2-10 mmHg in compliant users
AASM clinical practice guideline for diagnostic testing of OSA; PSG is gold standard; HSAT acceptable for uncomplicated patients
evidence.source: [Kapur et al. J Clin Sleep Med 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28162150/)

evidence.recommendation: Modafinil is effective for residual EDS in OSA patients adherent to CPAP; FDA-approved for this indication
evidence.source: [Black et al. Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17962641/)

evidence.recommendation: OSA is associated with increased prevalence of white matter hyperintensities and silent cerebral infarcts on MRI; severity correlates with AHI and hypoxemia burden
CPAP treatment for 3 months improves white matter integrity and neurocognitive function in severe OSA; structural brain changes are partially reversible
evidence.source: [Castronovo et al. Am J Respir Crit Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25233138/)

monitoring.item: CPAP compliance data (usage hours, AHI, mask leak)
monitoring.action: Address barriers (mask fit, pressure intolerance, claustrophobia); consider auto-CPAP, bilevel, or oral appliance if CPAP intolerant
Verify CPAP compliance; consider modafinil for residual EDS; evaluate for comorbid sleep disorder

monitoring.frequency: Annually; more frequently if decline suspected
monitoring.action: Formal neurocognitive testing; optimize CPAP; evaluate for concurrent neurodegenerative process
Optimize CPAP compliance (reduces BP 2-10 mmHg); adjust antihypertensives; evaluate for resistant hypertension

monitoring.item: Stroke risk stratification (CHA2DS2-VASc if atrial fibrillation)
monitoring.frequency: At diagnosis; annually; with new AF
monitoring.action: Initiate anticoagulation per guidelines; cardiology referral; aggressive CPAP compliance
Optimize CPAP first before adjusting AEDs; ensure weight-neutral AED selection; repeat EEG
Dietary counseling; exercise prescription; evaluate for bariatric surgery if BMI ≥35; adjust CPAP pressure after significant weight change
Initiate or intensify statin therapy; dietary modification
Endocrinology referral; lifestyle modification; CPAP compliance improves insulin sensitivity
Evaluate for persistent nocturnal hypoxemia if polycythemia; consider supplemental O2 with CPAP

disposition.criteria: Majority of OSA patients; initial evaluation, CPAP initiation, cognitive monitoring, stroke risk management, and long-term follow-up
Uncomplicated patients with high pretest probability; no significant cardiopulmonary, neuromuscular, or central apnea suspicion; moderate-to-high STOP-BANG score
Complex patients requiring attended study: suspected central apnea, concurrent seizure disorder requiring expanded EEG, neuromuscular disease, prior negative HSAT with high clinical suspicion

Acute ischemic stroke with known or newly diagnosed OSA; severe hypoxemia (SpO2 <85%) with neurological symptoms; obesity hypoventilation syndrome with encephalopathy; status epilepticus in patient with known OSA-epilepsy interaction
Acute respiratory failure with hypercapnic encephalopathy; massive stroke with airway compromise; refractory status epilepticus with OSA; severe obesity hypoventilation with respiratory acidosis
Cognitive decline with OSA; new-onset seizures in OSA patient; stroke or TIA evaluation; headache evaluation (morning headache pattern); neuropathy/autonomic dysfunction assessment
All patients for CPAP titration, compliance management, and long-term follow-up; evaluate for residual sleepiness; assess for comorbid sleep disorders
Every 2-4 weeks during CPAP initiation; every 1-3 months during first year; every 3-6 months once stable with annual neurocognitive screening
